Research Paper Blue LED-induced photocatalytic “Click” reaction facilitated by CuO/Bi2WO₆ for synthesising 1,4-disubstituted 1,2,3-triazoles Murugesan Shobika Writing – original draft Methodology Investigation Formal analysis a Selvaraj Mohana Roopan Writing – review & editing Supervision Conceptualization a ⁎ Jagannathan Madhavan Formal analysis Data curation b a Chemistry of Heterocycles and Natural Product Research Laboratory, Department of Chemistry, School of Advanced Sciences, Vellore Institute of Technology, Vellore 632014, Tamil Nadu, India Chemistry of Heterocycles and Natural Product Research Laboratory Department of Chemistry School of Advanced Sciences Vellore Institute of Technology Vellore Tamil Nadu 632014 India aChemistry of Heterocycles and Natural Product Research Laboratory, Department of Chemistry, School of Advanced Sciences, Vellore Institute of Technology, Vellore 632014, Tamil Nadu, India b Department of Chemistry, Thiruvalluvar University, Vellore, Tamil Nadu 632115, India Department of Chemistry Thiruvalluvar University Vellore Tamil Nadu 632115 India bDepartment of Chemistry, Thiruvalluvar University, Vellore, Tamil Nadu 632115, India ⁎ Correspondence authors. Azide-alkyne cycloaddition (CuAAC) is a key process in modern chemistry, enabling the efficient synthesis of molecules. Visible-light-induced photoredox catalysis offers an eco-friendly alternative to conventional thermal catalytic methods. In this study, CuO/Bi2WO6 (COB) heterojunctions are explored as photocatalysts for CuAAC under blue LED light, with minimal CuO loading on Bi2WO6 (BWO), demonstrating high efficacy in synthesizing disubstituted triazoles. The COB heterojunctions were thoroughly characterized using various techniques, including XRD, HRTEM, FTIR, BET, UV–vis DRS, FESEM, XPS, and EIS. HRTEM analysis indicated that the CuO in the composite exhibited an average size of 17.324 nm. The interaction between CuO and BWO promotes an electron transfer mechanism, improving photocatalytic efficiency and enabling Cu(II) to be photochemically reduced to Cu(I) in situ. Photocatalytic degradation studies and reactive oxygen species inhibition were used to support the mechanism. The COB catalyst achieved up to 91 % yield, with a high turnover number (TON: 33.7) and turnover frequency (TOF: 4.2 h⁻¹), and demonstrated high reusability over six cycles. A heterogeneity test confirmed the heterogeneity and non-leaching properties of the catalyst. These findings emphasize the potential of COB as a scalable, sustainable, and efficient catalyst for visible-light-driven copper-catalysed click reactions in modern synthetic chemistry. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords CuO Bi2WO6 Heterojunction Photocatalyst Blue LED Click reaction Triazole Redox catalyst 1 Introduction The discovery of new reaction pathways continues to advance synthetic organic chemistry. Among these, azide–alkyne cycloaddition (AAC) reaction is widely used due to its high selectivity for forming 1,2,3-triazoles, important structures in drugs for treating diabetes, cancer, and other diseases [1–8]. Since its introduction by Sharpless in 2001, click chemistry has emerged as a powerful and reliable approach in synthetic chemistry, drug discovery, biology, medical chemistry, and materials science [9–11]. The copper-catalysed azide–alkyne cycloaddition (CuAAC) remains the most commonly utilized click reaction, typically employing homogeneous Cu(I) or Cu(II) salts [12,13]. However, these conventional systems often suffer from limitations such as poor reusability, catalyst instability, and copper contamination issues that restrict their use in pharmaceutical and industrial applications. To overcome these challenges, visible-light-driven photo-redox catalysis has gained attention as a green alternative, as it has been widely reported in the literature as a powerful and sustainable strategy that utilizes light-induced electron transfer to drive chemical reactions, enabling the efficient synthesis of valuable compounds under mild conditions with broad applications in energy conversion and green chemistry [14–19]. It can activate click reactions while suppressing side reactions, using light as a clean energy source. Blue LEDs, with their high energy output in the visible spectrum, serve as an ideal light source for such reactions [20–22]. Nonetheless, most copper-based photocatalysts remain homogeneous, making recovery and reuse difficult. Heterogeneous systems offer a promising solution, with improved separation, environmental compatibility, and lower toxicity [23]. Bismuth tungstate (Bi₂WO₆ or BWO) is a visible-light-active semiconductor with excellent thermal and chemical stability and a layered structure that facilitates charge separation, making it a suitable support for photocatalysis [24,25]. However, its limitations, such as poor visible-light absorption, limited surface area, and rapid charge recombination reduce its catalytic efficiency [26]. To improve its performance, copper oxide (CuO), a narrow-bandgap semiconductor (∼2.0 eV) with high electrochemical activity and thermal stability, can be introduced [27–29]. CuO enhances light absorption and provides active sites for catalysis, but its use in CuAAC reactions has been relatively unexplored. Recent studies suggest that combining CuO with BWO could improve photocatalytic performance by enhancing charge separation and light utilization. Although some studies have examined thermal CuAAC reactions using these materials, the role of light and the underlying photo-redox mechanisms remain underexplored. In particular, no studies have addressed light-induced charge transfer, reactive oxygen species (ROS) generation, or photocatalytic radical pathways in such systems. In this study, we designed a CuO/Bi₂WO₆ (COB) heterojunction photocatalyst for visible-light-driven CuAAC reactions under blue LED irradiation. The Z-scheme heterojunction structure enhances charge separation and drives both oxidation and reduction processes essential for triazole formation. The COB catalyst demonstrated high selectivity, excellent stability, and recyclability (up to six cycles), achieving yields up to 91 % with excellent turnover number (TON) and turnover frequency (TOF). This work provides a sustainable and efficient photocatalytic system for green click chemistry, highlighting its potential in environmentally friendly organic synthesis. Scheme 1 . 2 Experimental section 2.1 Description of materials used The chemicals and reagents utilized for this experiment were obtained from Avra Laboratories Pvt. Ltd., Sigma-Aldrich, and TCI Pvt. Ltd. and were used without any extra purification. 2.2 Synthesis of COB catalyst The synthesis of BWO was carried out using the approach reported in our previous study [26,35]. Briefly, BWO was prepared via a hydrothermal process. Bi(NO3)3·5H2O (970.14 mg) was dissolved in 40 mL of water to achieve a 0.05 M concentration of solution A, whereas solution B was made by dissolving Na2WO4·2H2O (329.86 mg) in 20 mL of water to achieve the same concentration. The solutions (A and B) were stirred together for 2 h, followed by pH adjustment to 2 using 0.3 mL of 1 M HNO3. The obtained mixture was then transferred to a Teflon-lined autoclave (100 mL capacity) and treated hydrothermally at 160 °C for 24 h. After cooling to rt naturally, the resulting product was isolated by centrifugation, rinsed with ethanol and water, and then dried overnight at 60 °C, yielding the final BWO. Meanwhile, pristine CuO nanorods were synthesized using a straightforward precipitation approach, in which sodium hydroxide was added to an aqueous solution of copper acetate monohydrate, and the mixture was stirred for 4 h. The obtained product was repeatedly washed with deionized water to remove impurities, dried overnight at 80 °C, and subsequently calcined at 450 °C for further processing. To fabricate the composite, a simple grinding method was employed, wherein measured amounts of CuO (10 %, 20 %, and 30 % by weight) were added to BWO and ground for 20–30 min to ensure uniform dispersion. The well-mixed compound was loaded into a crucible and calcined at 200 °C for 2 h. The final composite was named x-COB, where “x” indicates the CuO weight percentage (10 %, 20 %, or 30 %) used in the synthesis (Fig. 1 ). 2.3 Characterization information For characterization details, see the supplementary data (Text S2). 2.4 General protocol for photocatalytic click reaction A mixture of propargyl indole-3-carbaldehyde (183 mg, 1.0 mmol), sodium azide (65 mg, 1.0 mmol), benzyl chloride (0.1 mL, 1.0 mmol), and 10 wt % of the 20COB catalyst has been prepared in a 15 mL glass vial containing 3 mL of acetonitrile. The reaction was carried out at ambient temperature under constant stirring while being irradiated with blue LEDs (12 W, 450–495 nm). Progress was monitored by TLC, and upon completion, the reaction was quenched with crushed ice. The resulting mixture was extracted with ethyl acetate, dried over anhydrous Na2SO4, and concentrated using a rotary evaporator. The crude product was purified by column chromatography (ethyl acetate/petroleum ether) to afford compound 4a as a white solid. Additionally, UV–vis analysis revealed that the catalyst has an absorption edge near 450 nm, which closely matches the emission peak of the blue LED used in the experiments. This spectral alignment enables efficient light absorption, enhances charge carrier generation, and improves photocatalytic efficiency under mild conditions. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 XRD analysis X-Ray Diffraction (XRD) is a reliable technique for studying the phase and structure of nanocrystals, covering diffraction angles (2θ) from 10° to 90° Fig. 2a presents the XRD patterns for BWO, CuO, and COB nanocomposites. The XRD pattern of CuO closely matches the monoclinic phase of CuO (JCPDS No. 45–0937), with no signs of impurities [36]. The observed CuO peaks at 32.86°, 35.88°, 39.03°, 49.13°, 53.79°, 58.58°, and 61.86° correspond to the (110), (002), (111), (202), (020), (202), and (113) planes. The results also verify the formation of BWO, consistent with JCPDS card #39–0256 [37]. The BWO peaks appear at 28.72°, 33.28°, 47.53°, 56.36°, and 58.93°, corresponding to planes (131), (200), (202), (133), and (262), confirming an orthorhombic phase [38,39]. In the 20COB nanocomposite, the BWO peaks show slight shifts to 2θ values of 28.09°, 32.65°, 35.31°, 38.50°, 46.92°, 55.59°, and 58.35°. The average crystallite sizes for pristine BWO and CuO were calculated by applying the Scherrer equation (Eq. (1)): (1) D = K λ / ( β cos θ ) In this equation, D denotes the crystallite size, λ represents the X-ray wavelength (0.154 nm), K is the Scherrer constant (0.9), and β corresponds to the full width at half maximum (FWHM). Pristine BWO and CuO exhibited crystallite sizes of 20.7 nm and 8.5 nm, respectively. In the 20COB nanocomposite, the size decreased to 19.7 nm, indicating the confined addition of CuO and its important role in the composite. 3.2 FTIR analysis FTIR analysis was employed to identify the surface functional groups present in the synthesized materials [40], providing insights into their bonding and chemical composition. As shown in Fig. 2b, the peaks were observed for BWO at 425 cm⁻¹, 863 cm⁻¹, and 737 cm⁻¹, corresponding to the W−O, Bi−O, and O−W−O stretching vibrations [41]. Additionally, a distinct peak between 400 and 600 cm⁻¹ was observed for CuO, which is linked to Cu−O stretching vibrations [42]. These results confirm that the synthesized nanocomposite contains both BWO and CuO. 3.3 UV–vis DRS analysis The optical behaviour of the synthesized materials was thoroughly characterized using UV–vis DRS, which provides valuable insights into their photocatalytic potential. These properties depend on factors like size, shape, and crystal structure. The absorption range and band gap energy obtained from UV–vis analysis are key parameters influencing photocatalytic efficiency. As illustrated in Fig. 3a , CuO exhibits a strong light absorption across 300–800 nm along with a narrow band gap, indicating its potential for effective photocatalytic performance. On the other hand, BWO shows a distinct absorption edge around 455 nm in the visible spectrum [43]. Notably, when CuO was coupled with BWO, the absorption edge moved to a longer wavelength (red shift), indicating better photocatalytic efficacy in visible light. Furthermore, the bandgap energies of the materials were determined using Tauc’s plot and the corresponding equation (Eq. (2)). (2) ( α h ν ) n = A ( h ν − E g ) where α is the absorption coefficient, A is a constant, hν represents photon energy, Eg​ denotes the bandgap energy, and n indicates the nature of the electronic transition (½ for indirect and 2 for direct transitions). The Tauc plots of (αhν)² versus hν (Fig. 3b) indicate that the bandgaps of BWO, CuO, and 20COB are 2.84 eV, 1.28 eV, and 2.18 eV, respectively. Notably, the intermediate bandgap of 20COB appears to facilitate its improved photocatalytic activity. To gain further insights into the photocatalytic mechanism, valence band X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (VB-XPS) was employed to determine the valence band (VB) potentials (EVB) of BWO and CuO. As shown in Fig. S1a and S1b, the EVB​ values for BWO and CuO were measured to be 3.28 eV and 1.40 eV, respectively, with their corresponding bandgap energies reconfirmed as 2.84 eV and 1.28 eV (Fig. 3b). Using these values, the conduction band (CB) potentials (ECB) were derived using Eq. (3). (3) E CB = E VB − E g Where, EVB and ECB denote the energy levels at the valence and conduction band edges, respectively, while Eg denotes the bandgap energy. Based on these calculations, CuO exhibits VB and CB positions at 1.40 eV and 0.12 eV, while BWO shows corresponding values of 3.28 eV and 0.44 eV. These band edge positions confirm that the system follows a Z-scheme mechanism, enabling efficient charge transfer and improved photocatalytic performance. 3.4 PL and EIS analysis Photoluminescence (PL) spectroscopy was used to study the recombination behaviour of photoinduced electrons and holes in the 20COB composite [44]. A decrease in PL intensity typically reflects a lower electron–hole recombination rate. As illustrated in Fig. 3c, the PL signal of the 20COB composite decreases with increasing CuO content, suggesting more efficient separation of photogenerated carriers. This improvement can be attributed to the formation of a CuO/BWO heterojunction, which effectively narrows the bandgap and promotes charge carrier separation. Additionally, the electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurements were conducted for BWO, CuO, and 20COB catalysts, and the resulting Nyquist plots are presented in Fig. 3d. The EIS plot of the 20COB composite shows a straight line at low frequencies in the Nyquist plot, which indicates Warburg impedance. This means ion diffusion plays a key role in the electrochemical process. The porous and rough surface of the COB material helps ion movement, supporting diffusion-controlled behaviour. The absence of a clear semicircle at high frequencies further suggests low charge-transfer resistance and fast interfacial charge transport. 3.5 Morphology analysis The structure and shape of the 20COB composite were studied using FE-SEM analysis. The images (Fig. 4a ) show that CuO has a nanorod shape, while BWO has a nanosheet shape, confirming that the CuO nanorods are well-integrated with the BWO sheets. Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) analysis (Fig. 4b) confirmed the presence of Bi, W, O, and Cu in the composite. Additionally, elemental mapping images (Fig. 4c–g) demonstrate a homogeneous distribution of these elements, particularly showing that CuO is uniformly dispersed across the BWO surface. The HRTEM images (Fig. 5a –c) show that BWO (nanosheet-like) and CuO (nanorod-like) form a heterojunction. In the 20COB composite (Fig. 5e), different lattice fringes are observed. The interplanar distances of 0.313 nm (Fig. S4b) and 0.275 nm (Fig. S4c) correspond to the (131) [45] and (200) planes of BWO, while the 0.235 nm distance (Fig. S4d) corresponds to the (111) plane of CuO [45]. The selectedarea electron diffraction (SAED) pattern (Fig. 5d) displays distinct diffraction rings, confirming the polycrystalline nature and high crystallinity of the 20COB composite. These findings further verify the successful formation of heterojunctions between BWO and CuO. Such coupling results in a modified band structure, effectively narrowing the bandgap and facilitating improved separation of photogenerated electron–hole pairs. Additionally, the average particle size of CuO within the 20COB composite was found to be 17.324 nm (Fig. 5f). 3.6 XPS analysis The elemental composition and oxidation states of the BWO, CuO, and the 20COB nanocomposite were determined by XPS analysis, as depicted in Fig. 6 . The survey spectra (Fig. 6a) revealed the presence of Bi, W, and O in pure BWO; Cu and O in pure CuO; and Bi, W, O, and Cu in the 20COB composite. Fig. 6b showed the Bi 4f chemical states, with peaks at 164.28 eV for BWO and 164.43 eV for 20COB corresponding to Bi 4f5/2, and peaks at 158.98 and 159.12 eV corresponding to Bi 4f7/2, indicating Bi3+. From Fig. 6c, the observed peaks at 35.05 eV for BWO and 35.17 eV for 20COB attributed to W 4f7/2, while the peaks at 37.14 eV for BWO and 37.24 eV for 20COB assigned to W 4f5/2, indicating that W was present in the W6+ state [46]. The O 1 s XPS spectra (Fig. 6d) showed that the binding energy of CuO at 529.59 eV was due to the Cu-O bond, while BWO at 529.99 eV showed Bi-O and W-O bonds. In 20COB, the peak at 530.15 eV was attributed to Cu-O bonds and surface lattice oxygens from BWO. Additional peaks at 531.16, 531.53, and 531.56 eV for CuO, BWO, and 20COB, respectively, were associated with OH groups as a result of surface-adsorbed water. The Cu 2p high-resolution spectra (Fig. 6e) showed that Cu 2p3/2 peaks for CuO and 20COB were at 933.88 and 933.63 eV, while Cu 2p1/2 peaks were at 953.84 and 953.52 eV, respectively, indicating Cu2+. The existence of the Cu²⁺ state in CuO was also confirmed by satellite peaks at 941.56, 943.84, and 962.15 eV. The observed shift in binding energy suggested changes in electron density at the surface. An increase in binding energy corresponds to a decrease in electron density, whereas a decrease in binding energy reflects an increase in electron density. Compared to BWO, the W 4f and Bi 4f binding energies of 20COB were slightly higher, while the Cu 2p binding energy was lower compared to CuO. This suggested electron transfer from BWO to CuO due to interactions at the 20COB interface [43,47]. 3.7 Brunauer Emmett Teller (BET) analysis The catalyst surface area and pore structure play a crucial role in determining photocatalytic performance. Fig. 7a depicts absorption-desorption of N₂ isotherms of the sample prepared. The nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms of all samples were classified as Type IV with a small H3 hysteresis loop [47,48], reflecting mesoporous structures. The BET surface areas were 41.683 m²/g for CuO, 18.711 m²/g for BWO, and 12.266 m²/g for 20COB (Table 1 ). Although the surface area of 20COB was slightly smaller than BWO, its photocatalytic efficiency for organic transformation was much higher, showing that surface area is not the main factor influencing photocatalytic performance [48]. Pore volumes of CuO, BWO, and 20COB were 0.196, 0.041, and 0.048 cm3/g, respectively, indicating that CuO addition has a relatively minor impact on the porosity of BWO. However, the average pore diameter of 20COB was larger than that of BWO [47] because adding CuO nanoparticles creates extra voids or disrupts the pore structure. This enhances molecule access to active sites, improving photocatalytic efficiency. The BJH pore size distribution (Fig. 7b) indicates that BWO, CuO, and 20COB possess pore sizes of 1.220 nm, 2.734 nm, and 1.676 nm, respectively. 3.8 Photocatalytic activity of synthesised 20COB catalyst The superior efficacy of the COB catalyst compared to other heterogeneous photocatalysts was systematically evaluated through its photocatalytic performance in a photo-triggered Click reaction involving alkynes, azides, and aryl/alkyl halides. To establish a benchmark, a model reaction comprising N-propargylated indole-3-carbaldehyde, sodium azide, and benzyl chloride was performed under aerobic conditions. No product formation was observed in the absence of a catalyst, even after extended exposure to blue LED irradiation (Table 2 , entry 1). Similarly, the addition of conventional additives such as NaOH, sodium ascorbate, and ascorbic acid failed to promote the reaction (Table 2, entries 2–4). In contrast, Cu-based catalysts such as CuO, Cu₂O, and a 1:1 CuO/BWO combination exhibited moderate catalytic activity, yielding 55 %, 53 %, and 62 %, respectively (Table 2, entries 6–8). The pure BWO catalyst failed to generate the target product under identical conditions (Table 2, entry 5). However, CuO-loaded BWO catalysts (COB) with varied CuO loading (10 %, 20 %, and 30 %) demonstrated a remarkable enhancement in photocatalytic efficiency, achieving yields between 69 % and 76 % (Table 2, entries 9–11). Notably, the 20COB catalyst, with an optimized CuO loading of 20 %, exhibited the highest catalytic performance, achieving a yield of 76 %. Further increasing the CuO loading did not enhance the yield, confirming 20COB as the optimal catalyst for subsequent studies. When the reaction was conducted under a nitrogen (N₂) atmosphere, the yield improved significantly to 91 % (Table 2, entry 12). This enhancement is attributed to the suppression of reactive oxygen species (ROS) under an inert atmosphere, thereby minimizing unreacted reactants or side reactions that adversely affect product yield. Conversely, reactions conducted in air resulted in lower yields due to the formation of ROS. The role of light in the reaction was further investigated. Under visible-light illumination, the reaction achieved a 56 % yield (Table 2, entry 14), demonstrating the efficacy of mixed wavelengths in the visible spectrum (λ > 420 nm). UV light irradiation (λ = 365 nm), however, failed to initiate the reaction (Table 2, entry 15), consistent with the UV–vis DRS spectrum of the 20COB catalyst, which predominantly absorbs in the visible region. Reactions conducted in complete darkness, regardless of the atmosphere, afforded only trace amounts of the product (Table 2, entries 13 and 16), underscoring the indispensable role of light. Under purely thermal conditions, a moderate yield of 51 % was observed, potentially due to catalyst leaching (Table 2, entry 17). Additives such as NaOH and sodium ascorbate were tested in combination with the 20COB catalyst (Table 2, entries 18 and 19) but were found unnecessary, as the reaction proceeded efficiently without them. Solvent effects were also investigated. Polar aprotic solvents, including DCM, DMF, and DMSO, yielded better outcomes (Table 2, entries 23–25), with ACN proving to be the optimal solvent. In contrast, polar protic solvents (e.g., ethanol, water) exhibited poor performance (Table 2, entries 20 and 21), likely due to their hole-scavenging effects, while nonpolar toluene afforded only minimal product formation (Table 2, entry 22). For further optimization of the click reaction, the effects of parameters such as light intensity, reaction time, solvents, catalyst, and catalyst dosage were systematically studied (see Supplementary Information, Tables S1–S5). As shown in Table 2, the lower yield observed under aerobic conditions can be attributed to the involvement of molecular oxygen in undesirable side reactions. Under visible-light illumination, oxygen can react with photoexcited electrons to generate reactive oxygen species (ROS), including superoxide (•O₂⁻) and singlet oxygen (¹O₂). These ROS can non-selectively oxidize intermediates or the final triazole product, reducing overall yield. Additionally, oxygen acts as an electron scavenger, limiting the availability of photogenerated electrons for the desired redox processes. This leads to unreacted starting materials or by-product formation. These effects were further confirmed by ROS detection using the methylene blue degradation experiment. The optimized reaction was tested on various aryl and alkyl halides, giving yields between 47 % and 91 %. Benzyl halides with electron-withdrawing groups (like nitro, cyano, and halogens) showed yields of 47 % to 85 % (Table 3 , entries 4b-4i). In contrast, those with electron-donating groups (like methoxy) gave slightly lower yields of 63 % to 66 % (Table 3, entries 4j and 4k). Long-chain alkyl halides resulted in moderate yields of 66 % to 71 % (Table 3, entries 4l and 4m). However, the unsubstituted aryl halide produced the highest yield under these conditions (Table 3, entry 4a). This work pioneers the use of blue LED irradiation for a photo-click reaction in an indole moiety, demonstrating a sustainable, energy-efficient approach to copper-based catalysis. Blue LEDs effectively provide visible light essential for activating the 20COB catalyst. This novel approach highlights the potential of blue LED-mediated photocatalysis in advancing green chemical synthesis. Comprehensive spectral characterization data such as ¹H and ¹³C NMR, FTIR, and HR-MS for the synthesized compounds, are available in the Supporting Information (see Supplementary Information, Tables S6). 3.9 Evaluation of the photocatalytic mechanism Fig. 8 shows the proposed photocatalytic mechanism of the Click reaction. When exposed to visible light, the COB photocatalyst becomes active, causing the alkyne (I) to oxidize into a radical cation (Ia) through single-electron transfer (SET), likely in the valence band (VB) of BWO. At the same time, azide (IIa) forms from the reaction of alkyl or aryl halide (II) with sodium azide. The radical cation (Ia) then reacts with the azide (IIa), creating a radical intermediate (III), which quickly cyclizes to form intermediate (IIIa). Finally, the COB catalyst reduces intermediate (IIIa) into the desired triazole product, possibly in the conduction band (CB) of CuO [49]. In the proposed Z-scheme heterojunction between CuO and BWO, upon visible-light irradiation, both semiconductors absorb photons and generate e-/h + pairs. The CB of BWO is positioned at a more negative potential than the VB of CuO. This band position allows the transfer of photogenerated electrons from the CB of BWO to recombine with the photogenerated holes in the VB of CuO. This electron–hole recombination across the interface is energetically favorable due to the potential difference between the CB of BWO and the VB of CuO and is driven by electrostatic interactions at the heterojunction interface. Furthermore, strong interfacial coupling and the formation of an internal electric field at the CuO/BWO interface enhance charge separation and promote directional charge migration. As a result, holes remaining in the VB of BWO and electrons remaining in the CB of CuO possess higher redox potentials, which are crucial for the photocatalytic reactions. This synergistic interaction within the Z-scheme heterojunction not only prolongs charge carrier lifetimes but also ensures sufficient oxidative and reductive power, enabling efficient triazole synthesis under visible light. To enhance the clarity and focus of the main content of the text, we have moved the detailed studies, such as evaluating charge transfer in the photocatalyst system, scavenging and trapping studies, methylene blue degradation analysis, catalyst reusability and stability tests, and the heterogeneity study of the 20COB photocatalyst, and so on to the Supporting Information (Text S3.1–S3.6 and Fig. S1–S4). These results support the proposed reaction mechanism and show that the 20COB catalyst is stable and reusable. 3.10 Scalability test A gram-scale reaction was performed to assess the scalability of the proposed catalytic system. Specifically, the reaction was carried out using propargyl indole-3-carbaldehyde (1.83 g, 10 equiv., 10 mmol), sodium azide (0.65 g, 10 equiv., 10 mmol), and benzyl chloride (1.26 mL, 10 equiv., 10 mmol) in the presence of 10 wt % of the 20COB catalyst. The reactants were mixed with 3 mL of ACN, the solvent established for smaller-scale reactions which yielded above 85 % yield. The results showed that the catalyst maintained its activity and efficiency at a larger scale, indicating its potential for industrial applications. 4 Conclusion and future aspects In conclusion, this study highlights the effectiveness of CuO/Bi2WO6 (COB) heterojunctions as efficient photocatalysts for visible-light-driven azide–alkyne cycloaddition (CuAAC) reactions. The optimized CuO loading on Bi₂WO₆ (BWO) demonstrated exceptional catalytic performance, achieving up to 91 % yield in the synthesis of disubstituted triazoles under blue LED illumination. Comprehensive characterization, including HRTEM analysis, confirmed an average CuO particle size of 17.324 nm, providing insights into the functional and structural features of the catalyst. The strong interfacial interaction between CuO and BWO facilitates efficient electron transfer and enables the in situ photoreduction of Cu(II) to Cu(I), thereby enhancing photocatalytic activity. Photocatalytic degradation studies and reactive oxygen species inhibition experiments further validated the proposed reaction mechanism. The COB catalyst exhibited excellent stability and reusability over six consecutive cycles, with high turnover numbers (TON) and turnover frequencies (TOF). Heterogeneity tests confirmed its heterogeneous nature and negligible leaching of copper species. Moreover, the catalyst worked well in inert conditions, using nitrogen (N₂) to prevent ROS formation. This helped achieve a high yield of 91 %. The broad substrate scope, including various halides and aliphatic halides, underscores the versatility of this catalytic system. These findings establish COB as a highly efficient, reusable, and environmentally sustainable photocatalyst for visible-light-driven CuAAC reactions. The study paves the way for its potential application in green and scalable synthetic methodologies, further advancing the development of eco-friendly copper-catalyzed click chemistry. coredata.dc:description: Azide-alkyne cycloaddition (CuAAC) is a key process in modern chemistry, enabling the efficient synthesis of molecules. Visible-light-induced photoredox catalysis offers an eco-friendly alternative to conventional thermal catalytic methods. In this study, CuO/Bi2WO6 (COB) heterojunctions are explored as photocatalysts for CuAAC under blue LED light, with minimal CuO loading on Bi2WO6 (BWO), demonstrating high efficacy in synthesizing disubstituted triazoles. The COB heterojunctions were thoroughly characterized using various techniques, including XRD, HRTEM, FTIR, BET, UV–vis DRS, FESEM, XPS, and EIS. HRTEM analysis indicated that the CuO in the composite exhibited an average size of 17.324 nm. The interaction between CuO and BWO promotes an electron transfer mechanism, improving photocatalytic efficiency and enabling Cu(II) to be photochemically reduced to Cu(I) in situ. Photocatalytic degradation studies and reactive oxygen species inhibition were used to support the mechanism. The COB catalyst achieved up to 91 % yield, with a high turnover number (TON: 33.7) and turnover frequency (TOF: 4.2 h⁻¹), and demonstrated high reusability over six cycles. A heterogeneity test confirmed the heterogeneity and non-leaching properties of the catalyst. These findings emphasize the potential of COB as a scalable, sustainable, and efficient catalyst for visible-light-driven copper-catalysed click reactions in modern synthetic chemistry.
